title: Tuesday, 6th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am

PM

If only I could share some of the email to-and-fro from that. But I can't. So let's move on.

undefined

So Footsie drifting

11:11 am

6855

BE

So we have banks drifting a wee bit.

11:11 am
PM

This generalised low interest rate fretting?

PM

Pressure on NIM

BE

Yeah, that's the theme. Much as the Deutsche note you quoted yesterday.

11:13 am
BE

Banks get NIM crushed, have to chase volume to offset, can only chase volume with price, and get their NIM crushed even more.

BE

Today, though, we also have a Barclays downgrade o Stan.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 646.90, down 11.6 (-1.76%), High: 653.00, Low: 645.80, Volume: 1.73m
11:14 am
BE

Sector piece. Long.

BE

Differentiating on macro and valuation: While there has been some recent optimism,
medium-term prospects for European banking profitability generally remain challenging
and we believe that a high proportion of business outside Europe has been one of the
key drivers of Standard Chartered’s and HSBC’s outperformance so far this year. In this
report we take a detailed look at these two banks together with BBVA and Santander,
assessing prospects for economic growth, interest rates and currencies in their key
geographies and comparing valuations to our geographic sum-of-the-parts analysis.
We see aggregate macro prospects and valuation as most supportive for Santander and
upgrade it to Overweight with a €4.70 price target and upgrade BBVA to Equal Weight
with a new price target of €6.20. Despite a supportive macro backdrop for Standard
Chartered, we see the valuation as overshooting its earnings power and downgrade to
Underweight with a 520p price target. We stay Equal Weight on HSBC.

BE

Aggregate macro most supportive for Santander and BBVA: Overall, we see
Santander’s and BBVA’s footprints as best positioned with weaker prospects for HSBC
and Standard Chartered. We expect the strongest footprint-weighted GDP acceleration
from Santander which also benefits from higher interest rates and reducing FX
headwinds. BBVA shares many of these characteristics apart from a slight GDP
slowdown but from a stronger starting point. In contrast, we expect some slowdown
for HSBC and some increase in the FX headwind for Standard Chartered. With c40% of
their business in the UK, US and Mexico, Santander, BBVA and HSBC could benefit most
directly if there is effective fiscal stimulus in the US and UK.

11:14 am
BE

SoTP valuation also suggests most opportunity in Santander and BBVA: While all
four banks currently trade on lower multiples than their footprint-weighted peer groups
with discounts of 20-40%, we expect HSBC and Standard Chartered to generate
significantly lower RoTEs than peers while BBVA and Santander’s returns are expected
to be broadly in line. On a return adjusted basis, Santander is the most attractively
valued relative to its SoTP at a 41% discount, followed by BBVA, while Standard
Chartered looks the most expensive on a 25% premium.

BE

Noting the negatives: We continue to see the capital positions of Santander and BBVA as
adequate but relatively weak although sum-of-the-parts valuations still look attractive
after normalising for capital as well as returns. The political situation in Spain also remains
an area of uncertainty, and for BBVA geopolitical risk in Turkey is a key consideration but
again reflected in our valuation. We believe that a de-rating of Standard Chartered will
require the market to refocus on relatively weak, albeit improving, earnings.

BE

And we can jump to the STAN section.

11:17 am
BE

Management actions have stabilised the business with revenues appearing to have
bottomed out and provisions now relatively steady at still elevated levels but significantly
better than 2015. There has also been early progress on restructuring although this is likely
to be a lengthy process with the initial target of an 8% RoE by 2018 now pushed back.
While we see the macro outlook as relatively supportive and expect earnings to continue
improving, we believe that the valuation has now significantly disconnected from the
medium-term earnings potential of the business. As a result we downgrade the shares to
Underweight with a 520p price target but acknowledge that a de-rating will require the
market to refocus on stock specifics rather than the broader macro environment.

BE

Bull points
• Strengthened balance sheet and stabilised profitability - Income has stabilised after
several years of significant decline with provisions also reducing following the
completion of the balance sheet clean up.
• Strong capital – 13.1% CET1 ratio which we expect to improve further from 2017.
• Reasonably supportive macro – Strong footprint GDP with further growth in 2017,
relatively supportive interest rates but an FX headwind.
• Diversified footprint – Across Asia, Africa and the Middle East
Bear points
• Significant disconnect between earnings power and valuation – Both a fundamental
analysis and return-adjusted peer comparison suggest that the shares are overvalued by
20%.
• Early stage restructuring, slow improvement from here – The business has been
stabilised but work on restructuring and repositioning has only just begun.
• RoE targets below peers and being pushed back – Management expect the 8% RoE
targeted for 2018 to now take longer to achieve.

PM

(Btw -- i had promised to share HSBC stuff in the usual place, but posted a gold note by accident. Issue now fixed: http://discussions...f-worry/uk-banks-3 )

11:17 am
PM

(Note -- Limey)

undefined
BE

On the flipside, I guess we need to do DPL.

11:18 am
PM

I think we do

BE

Redrow and Berkeley on the tape, both as good as can be expected.

PM

Berkeley: http://www.investe...1609060700080073J/

11:19 am
PM

Redrow: http://www.investe...1609060700080088J/

BE

There was a lot of noise ahead of Berkeley's updates .... Essentially, everyone who's short said "we're hearing reservations have slumped around 20% since Brexit" and everyone on the sellside said, "yes, we know and don't care."

BE

The sellside wins, as it turns out. Berkeley reservations are weakish, but not unexpectedly so.

11:21 am
BE

(@Borncynic: indeed! And MOST was pushing it yesterday. I'll dig out the note, if you're interested.)

PM

Berkeley sending sackfuls of cash back to shareholders

PM

This visibility of cash flow and earnings also underpins the Company's dividend plan, of which the next £1.00 interim dividend per share is payable to shareholders on 15 September 2016 (£137 million), bringing the total returns paid to shareholders since 2011 to £6.34, with a further £10 per share to be paid evenly over the remaining 5 years to September 2021. Following the dividend payment and taking into account the £20 million spent on acquiring the Company's shares on 24 June, Berkeley expects to remain ungeared at the 31 October 2016 half year, with the actual level of cash dependent on the extent and timing of land and build investment.

11:22 am
BE

Yep -- that's a 7% divi to help you not worry about the top end of the London market collapsing.

BE

There was a rather slow bowl piece on the local London news last night about foreign buyers no longer buying prime property .....

BE

... because you're taxed much less buying ten two-bedroom flats in Zone 6 than you are buying one flat in Zone 1.

11:24 am
BE

http://www.bbc.co....es-the-eu-37260267

PM

hmm

BE

Unintended consequence of the stamp duty changes. We end up with swathes of suburban housing owned by absentee landlords.

11:24 am
BE

But back to Berkeley.

BE

Here's Deutsche to summarise where it is.

BE

The trading update from Berkeley highlights that while London continues weaker, pricing has remained resilient and ahead of group budget. This combined with the strong forward order book (equivalent to 75% of revenues to FY 18) combines to allow management the confidence to reiterate FY 16-18 PBT, and we believe there will be little change to consensus forecasts. With its demotion from the FTSE 100 compounding concerns of the impact of Brexit and the London housing market as a whole, Berkeley’s share price performance over the summer has been weak. However, with the stock now yielding 7.4%, net cash on the balance sheet, and a robust and lengthy land bank, we continue to see the group as undervalued: BUY.

11:25 am
BE

As usual within this IMS there is no numerical update on the group’s order book. However the statement reports August reservations have returned to the same level seen for the first 5 months of the calendar year (after a hiatus either side of the referendum), but that that in itself is down 20% YoY. Some of this management attributes to lower number of sites (we know site launches significantly benefited the comparable for the first 5 months) but also the market as a whole. Better is the site visitors and enquiries data which are reported flat YoY, leading management to think the customer taking longer to decide rather than leaving the market. The group talks of resilient pricing since Brexit (and above business plans which were set in Nov 15) and moving back to a normal cancellation rate in August.

BE

Within the statement Berkeley reiterated guidance £2bn PBT FY 16-18 (DB ests £2.1bn, consensus £1.9bn). Key to this is the (legally exchanged) order book which was reported at YE 16 to be £4.35bn - equivalent to 75% of next 2 years revenue (the statement today highlights the good visibility over the coming 2 years) – for which the group holds 25% deposits. While the declining reservation rates suggest that this order book may have seen limited progression, we recognise that much of the unreserved land bank consists of lower priced product for the latter part of FY 18 onwards.

BE

Within the statement Berkeley highlights matching capital investment with market demand, suggests the group may be a little more cautious on WIP (we hear of a site in Barnes where build out has been stopped) and land investment (the group has only bought 2 sites in the period), and it guides to net cash at H1 17. The group has reiterated its dividend plans (another 5 years of 200p div pa, £274m pa) and even on our forecasts which assume continued WIP investment (£300m pa FY 17 & 18) we believe this dividend can be paid without the company going into any meaningful net debt position.

11:25 am
BE

And Jefferies, saying much the same.

BE

It may have fallen out of the FTSE 100 but Berkeley hasn’t fallen over as it re-iterates guidance for delivering £2.0bn of pre-tax profit over the three years ending 30 April 2018. With the attractive dividend underpinned by cash we remain buyers of the shares.

Reservations remain at 20% below the prior year, reflecting a combination of lower product availability and market conditions, however site visitors and enquiry levels are similar to last year, demonstrating the strength of demand, even though homebuyers are taking longer to commit. With a nod towards the Autumn statement Berkeley’s statement today suggests that stamp duty for buyers and Infrastructure levies for developers are causing the London housing market to stall.

PM

How about Redrow

11:26 am
PM

?

PM

The thing is up 7 per cent

BE

11:27 am
Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 411.00, up 26.7 (+6.95%), High: 416.90, Low: 400.00, Volume: 1.23m
BE

PM

Seen no Brexit impact at all, apparently

11:28 am
BE

New year started well. Looking at headline upgrades around the 3% level, I think.

BE

Which is a consequence of -- sorry to be boring! -- a structurally undersupplied market that doesn't therefore respond to wee things like consumer confidence or employment prospects.

BE

It responds firstly to mortgage availability, which is where we spin back to the banks at the top, all chasing volume on ever decreasing margins.

11:30 am
BE

Housebuilders are a state-protected cartel and a racket. Convince me otherwise.

BE

In the meantime, here's Davy.

BE

Redrow has released full-year results. Revenue was 20% higher than FY 2014/15 as previously flagged, with volumes increasing by 17%. Pre-tax profit was �250m for the year, 23% ahead of last years' result and in line with the guidance provided in June. The company has entered the year with a strong order book amounting to �897m, 51% higher than last year. Sales have been strong since the start of the financial year (July): the first ten weeks have seen sales 8% higher than the same period last year, despite a strong comparator.

11:31 am
BE

Actually, that's the wrong email. Those are just desk notes. Sorry, try this one.

BE

After a quick-fire trading statement to reassure the market following the Brexit vote, strong sales have continued at Redrow well into the new financial year. The company continues to position itself for growth and today’s announcement adds to the list of builders seeing a big rebound in activity after a nervous couple of weeks at the start of July.

BE

Results in line with expectations
Redrow has released full-year results (September 6th). Revenue was 20% higher than FY 2014/15 as previously flagged, with volumes increasing by 17%. The ASP was £288,600, up 7% compared with last year. The company saw operating margin increase by 40bps to 18.9%, driven entirely by increases in gross margin. Pre-tax profit was £250m for the year, 23% ahead of last year’s result and in line with the guidance provided in June.
Trading throughout the financial year was strong. The only region which has been sluggish was higher-end London, as previously flagged. Redrow’s exposure remains very limited here however.
Trading well since the EU referendum
Redrow has entered the year with a strong order book of £897m, 51% higher than last year. Sales have been strong since the start of the financial year (July): the first ten weeks have seen sales 8% higher than the same period last year despite a strong comparator. The company’s strategy remains to continue to grow the business and it has a strong pipeline of sites at present.

11:32 am
BE

And, oh I dunno, Canaccord?

BE

Results all look broadly in line with comments made in the recent trading update. PBT
of £250m is slightly higher than our expectation of £246.5m, with EPS up by +24% to
55.4p. A strong increase in the dividend, as expected, up by +67% to 10p. As expected,
strong results driven by a strong increase in completions with margins up slightly. Order
book is very strong at £807m (+54%) with site numbers at the year end also up strongly.
Focus will be on recent trading comments which read well and are consistent with
recent comments from peers that, outside of Central London, the market is holding
up well post the initial Brexit shock. For the first 10 weeks, sales are up by +8% (this
looks to be boosted by more site numbers but still a good number even if this is the
case). Management is confident of another year of significant progress and reiterated its
medium-term guidance targets (revenue of £1.6bn, EPS of 62p and RoE of 25%).
Consensus continues to have a very wide range based on differing macro views into
2017 but so far the new housing market is holding up and this is another house-builder
confirming that. While Redrow is relatively more leveraged versus peers, this should be
less of a concern assuming that the housing market continues to hold up better than the
bears had feared post Brexit, and shares remain one of the lowest rated in the sector.

BE

Shares have bounced strongly after the sharp sell-off post the Brexit vote. They are up by
+15% over the last month and up by over c.+39% from the recent lows. They reside on a
2016E P/NAV multiple of c.1.3 times versus the sector average of c.1.8 times and offer a
dividend yield of +c.4%.

11:32 am
PM

I'm not going to argue with you Bryce

PM

BE

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 350.40, up 18.1 (+5.45%), High: 353.80, Low: 331.50, Volume: 1.01m

Sports Direct will offer some of its casual staff on zero hours contracts permanent employment with guaranteed hours as part of reforms of working practices it admitted were “potentially oppressive”.
A report commissioned by the retailer and prepared by professional services company RPC found “serious shortcomings” at its Derbyshire warehouse “which the board deeply regrets and apologises for”.

BE

It said executive deputy chairman Mike Ashley accepted that as founder and majority shareholder he took “ultimate responsibility for any aspects of the working practices that were unsatisfactory, even where he is not in day-to-day control of these matters or had no knowledge of them”.

11:36 am

11:47 am
DS Smith PLC (SMDS:LSE): Last: 426.93, up 4.43 (+1.05%), High: 431.30, Low: 422.90, Volume: 982.12k
PM

http://www.investe...1609060700080112J/

BE

Which says everything's okay in the world of paper and packaging.

11:47 am
BE

Numbers in line, guidance unchanged.

BE

Here's UBS.

BE

The Company noted good volume growth in pan-Europe, with the company citing
the benefit from their increased scale and coverage, and there appears to have been no
change in trends post the UK referendum. The Gopaca transaction announced in June
is expected to complete in the first of this financial year.

11:48 am
BE

There is no change in company guidance. The outlook remains positive with a good
start to the year. Our operating profit forecast at £440m is at the upper end of
consensus (with the consensus mid-point just below £430m) – we have factored in a
full FX benefit from recent moves. We expect limited changes to consensus.

BE

An in line update should be seen as supportive but have limited share price impact.

BE

Yep, and so it transpired.

11:48 am
BE

Though it does give me an excuse to mention Smurfit as well.

BE

Which has been on a good run of late, probably on sector-wide price rises rather than anything more interesting, as we've said repeatedly here.

BE

Merrill catches up today.

11:50 am
BE

Cash is King: Upgrade to Buy We think investors now need to recognise SKG’s strong free cash generation and the potential equity value release this could afford even in bearish scenarios – with a sector-leading FCF yield, we upgrade the shares to Buy. Self-help investments have been made in recent years and we see capex falling materially in 2017E which could result in a 30% FCF CAGR over 2016-18E. Our revised 12m DCF-derived PO represents c17% potential upside, with the de-gearing opportunity likely driving further upside out to 2018E.

BE

Solid cash flow. Capex falling = cash flow getting better yet Cash flow has been strong historically and while a new capex programme is to be
established in ‘17E, management has indicated capex will fall to 100% of depreciation in
17E. Investors are thus likely to see a meaningful uplift in FCF (c45% y/y in 17E, on our
estimates). Our scenario analysis suggests that just by virtue of strong cash generation,
even if Smurfit were to see no earnings growth and merely hold its EV/EBITDA multiple,
a valuation of EUR29.93 by 18E could be possible – as net debt shrinks and the equity
portion of SKG’s EV expands.

BE

OCC climbing; containerboard improving. Pricing looks good We are increasingly seeing signs of optimism in recycled containerboard markets. Key
players are announcing price increases and OCC prices are rising strongly. SKG is leading
the pack – recently announcing a €40/ton testliner increase in Europe effective 12th
September. We estimate that the annualized impact if successful would be a c10% uplift
to EBITDA. We see a good chance of success given the cost-push from OCC Prices
which have been on a sharply rising trend in recent weeks and are currently +17% YTD.

11:51 am
BE

Best in class FCF yield. Screens well on range of metrics In our view the shares currently offer amongst the most attractive FCF yield in the
sector at c10.1% over 2016-19E – and arguably the best FCF yield value when
considering the yield in the context of downside risks and future growth prospects (both
areas in which it arguably scores more highly than the few peers with higher FCF yields).

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 1,990, up 30 (+1.53%), High: 2,019, Low: 1,988, Volume: 108.04k
BE

And that concludes today's containerboard corner.

11:51 am
undefined

BE

11:53 am

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 325.21, down 1.79 (-0.55%), High: 331.70, Low: 324.40, Volume: 3.01m
PM

And no statement

11:54 am
BE

BE

BE

11:54 am
undefined
PM

Repeated requests for Ashmore

PM

But is there much fresh to say?

11:55 am
PM

Shore still saying sell

BE

FY is broadly in line, and as ever, "broadly" means "not".

Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 356.30, up 1.3 (+0.37%), High: 360.00, Low: 338.50, Volume: 1.10m
11:56 am
BE

Outlook's okay. flows look pretty poor.

PM

Ashmore has reported final results for the year ended 30th June 2016. Total net revenue was down 18% at £232.5m (Shore : £232m, consensus* : £224m), EBITDA of £143.0m (Shore £142.3m, consensus £131m) and PBT down 8% at £167.5m (Shore : £145m, consensus : £134m) generating adjusted diluted eps down 7% at 18.1p (Shore : 15.6p, consensus : 14.9p). The main reason for the large beat at the PBT/eps level versus both our numbers and consensus appears to be the £24.6m mark-to-market gain on seed capital (Shore : £8.0m), a function of the stronger EMD markets in H2. Note that both the gain on holding dollar denominated cash on the balance sheet (£21.0m gain in the year just reported) and the seed capital gain are not recurring items and therefor have no implication for forecasts for y/e Jun 17. As expected, the dividend was held flat at 16.65p.

PM

Paul McGinnis the analyst there

11:56 am
PM

We fundamentally like the Ashmore business model and think that the way the company has consistently applied its highly active top-down investment process will have earned it considerable credibility with clients. Our issue is valuation. We downgraded our recommendation to Sell on 19th April when the share price went above 300p as we felt that a very material recovery in AuM was being priced-in somewhat prematurely on improved EM sentiment, particularly as net flows remained negative (and management’s caution today against expecting too rapid a rebound in flows). The shares last traded at current levels, apart from a very brief period in 2015, when AuM was over $70bn, so with the current 12m forward PER well above the long term sector average (c13.5x) on what we already regard as bullish Jun ’17 assumptions, we think there will be better opportunities to invest in this quality asset manager. Ahead of updating our model, our fair value is 275p and we retain a SELL recommendation.

BE

Just reading Barclays ............ 23 times 2017? Is that right?

BE

EM indices have continued to recover in Q3 (MSCI EM +9% July-Sep to date and 14% ytd) causing strong optimism in the Ashmore share price (+39% ytd vs FTSEAllshare +9%). Against these heightened expectations Ashmore hasn’t disappointed with FY16 underlying adjusted PBT (ex £24.6m seeding gains) of ~£143m which in line with consensus and a maintained FY DPS of 16.65p (4.7% yield). However, it also has not pushed recovery expectations higher, in our opinion. Outlook statement, although positive on EM outlook, cautions again for the speed with which its Institutional mandates may recover (vs faster money into EM ETFs or EM mutual funds). August performance fees which tend to form the bulk of Ashmore’s FY17 total are also muted at only £5.7m. AUM and flows details had already been released. The boost to FX revenues of £21m was even stronger than we expected (£17m) causing a 1% headline net revenue beat at £232.5m for FY16. Headline PBT of £167.5m was detailed as boosted by £24.6m of seed capital gains. Stripping these out the £143m adjusted PBT could be considered just in line with consensus per the company of £142.4m. This seeding gains boosts headline FY16 diluted EPS to 18.1p allowing management to declare a covered dividend at 16.65p (in line with consensus expectations).

11:57 am
BE

While management indicated that EM fundamentals are improving and have provided good investment opportunities to Ashmore’s value-based strategies, they stress that most institutional investors take longer to react to market changes and reflect these in their asset allocation decisions. Therefore there will likely be a lag in flows coming through as clients tend to want to see a longer period of market recovery. Further, they flag that some investors who mis-timed the cycle may want to use a period of strong asset prices to exit. On Brexit, management indicate that the immediate impact was an FX tailwind on translation gains on the Balance sheet and ongoing gains from USD denominated management fee (subject to hedges). The medium-term impact is less certain but ultimately they believe operational implications will be manageable. The Group has formed a senior committee to focus on managing three main areas – passporting of financial services, counterparty relationships and a small number of UK-based employees that are potentially affected.

PM

Yeah, Shore got it on 21x 2017

BE

The majority of Ashmore’s funds book performance fees in August. The statement detailed that at Aug £5.7m of performance fees has been booked to be reflected in the FY Jun-17 year. This is more muted than expected given the strong recovery in EM indices as well as Ashmore’s near-term fund performance. In the past management has guided to £20-25m being a “normal” level of performance fees. Performance fees in FY14-FY16 have significantly been below this at £3-13m p.a.

11:57 am
BE

In calendar Q3 to date MSCI EM equity index has risen 9% in July-Sep and is up 12% ytd. Noble of course remains a death-or-glory turnaround play. Morgan Stanley goes for the latter.

BE

Noble's liquidity crunch had been our key concern, but we
forecast an inflection ahead. Recovering coal prices should
boost confidence in the value of its offtake contracts. We
resume coverage at OW with a price target of S$0.23.

12:01 pm
BE

An inflection ahead: Noble has been battling a sharp loss in investor confidence
since 1Q15, when a series of whistle blower reports alleged accounting
irregularities at the company. More recently, the loss of its investment grade
credit rating and weak 1H16 operating performance has increased investor
concerns about its liquidity. But with the shares trading at just 0.3x 2Q16 BV
(proforma for its June 2016 rights issue), and management targeting liquidity
initiatives to raise US$2bn, we believe it offers a favorable risk reward.
Liquidity crunch to ease: Following its US$500mn rights issue, we believe
Noble's 2Q16 liquidity crunch is beginning to inflect. We forecast its liquidity
headroom to rebound from its 2Q16 lows, as it executes on the proposed sale of
Noble Americas Energy Solutions (NAES) and unlocks working capital from
restructured businesses. As a result of these actions we forecast a potential
reduction to Noble's May 2017 refinancing requirements to under US$1bn.
Confidence in asset values to return: Following a jump in coal prices, we believe
the carrying or net fair value (NFV) of Noble's Level 2 offtake contracts may be
conservative. For example, it recently impaired its long-term coal Anchor prices to
US$55/t, which is now about 10% below the Newcastle forward curve at roughly
US$60/t. As such, we believe confidence in the NFV of its offtake contracts
should return and support a market value closer to its reported book value.
Trading at 0.3x 2Q16 BV (proforma for its rights issue): The market haircuts
Noble's BV by about US$2.3bn, about one-half of which is due to market-implied
haircuts on its NFVs, which we now have more confidence in following the coal
price rebound. Management also highlighted that NAES is on track to be sold by
year-end 2016 at a price materially accretive to book value. Adjusting for both
adds back about one-half of the market's haircut to Noble's BV for our price
target of S$0.23/sh, which implies 0.7x BV, or 10x P/E and 9x EV/EBITDA in 2017.

BE

Where could we be wrong: Noble has to refinance US$2.3bn of short-term bank
debt in May-17; management aims to raise US$2bn of liquidity including the
proposed sale of NAES and working capital reductions. However, if these
initiatives were to be impaired or aborted it could lead to further deterioration in
Noble's liquidity position and its ability to refinance its short-term borrowings.

BE

Note, MOST was advising Noble on the sale of its US energy business

I will get share some CS UK macro stuff

PM

To address that point about walking back the post Brexit economic performance

PM

The negative impact of the UK’s vote to leave the EU on growth in the UK and
euro area appears to have been materially less than we expected in late June.
A range of indicators suggest that the euro area economy remained
remarkably resilient after the vote. And after a sharp fall in July, business
surveys have rebounded in the UK in August, suggesting that although the
economy should slow in H2, it is unlikely to experience a sharp recession such
as we forecast in June.
Consequently, we now forecast UK growth of +1.9% in 2016 and +0.5% in
2017 (vs +1.0% and -1.0% respectively), and euro area growth of 1.6% in
2016 and 1.5% in 2017 (vs 1.6% and 1.0%).

12:04 pm
PM

The prospects for the euro area look promising. Brexit marks yet another
potential “shock” that the economy has weathered well in the past couple of
years. Although GDP growth may slow a little from the 1.5% annualized pace
seen in the first half of 2016, the expansion should remain solid and selfsustaining,
driven by burgeoning domestic demand.
In the UK, resumed political stability, a weaker currency and the Bank of
England’s policy response look to have stabilized activity after confidence fell
sharply in the wake of the vote. That may be sufficient for GDP to avoid a
modest contraction.
But indicators are consistent with relatively weak growth, of around 0.5%
annualized. And we would expect this weakness to persist into 2017. Brexit will
probably sustain firm headwinds against the economy. We believe uncertainty
over the UK’s status in the single market will constrain corporate spending and
hiring, and weak labour incomes and higher inflation will constrain household
consumption. As such, we do not expect the economy to speed up materially
next year.

PM

The uncertainty around our UK forecasts remains high, and there are material
downside risks. Business behaviour may prove sensitive to the UK
government’s activation of Article 50, especially if the negotiations that follow
point to a loss of membership of the single market.
On the basis of our revised forecasts, we now do not expect a further rate cut
from the Bank of England until H1 2017, when it may become apparent that
the recovery that the Bank is forecasting in 2017 has failed to materialize.
